A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. If so, don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for more than one year during the period from 1870 to 1945.

1. Your full name: William H. Terry

2. Your address: 813 m. 8th St., S.E., Saskatoon, Saskatchewan

3. Date: March 19, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Paul Wisconsin, U.S.A.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: George Terry, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1901

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   Wisconsin 1874-1886
   Minnesota 1886-1890

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", etc.): I was 23 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? I came to work over the farm in the fall of 1901, and while there, I found a homestead on the Prairies, decided to come out and get a job.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

    Mostly government information from the Canadian Government Office in Paul

    During U.S.A. I was in Paul frequently and often spent more time in their office.
1. Your full name: William Terry

2. Your address: 813...8th St., South Bend, Indiana

3. Date: January 3rd, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Paul Watson, Okla.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: George Terry, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1901

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to South Dakota:

   Wisconsin 1874-1886
   Minnesota 1886/1902

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use an "I was a small child" if it was in your case).

   I was 2 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   I came to South over the Canadian Pacific Railroad in the fall of 1901 and while here I joined a Mormon Church. I then decided to come out and get a job in 1902.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    Mostly government information from the Canadian government Office in St. Paul.

    Mr. A.S.A. Johnson of Paul, originally and often spent a lot of time in your office.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought I was going to the end of the world, and they would never see me again.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

In the fall of 1901 I met a man named Mr. Armstrong at Moose Jaw and traveled with him during my stay there. In June 1902 I traveled in a car of settlement effects and a Buffalo Pole team through almost 50 miles of wilderness. The effects were excellent for our needs.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the Windsor Hotel, Regina, where we stayed for a short time.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Saskatchewan, near Moose Jaw.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived at Regina, Saskatchewan, from 1908 to early 1911.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Farmers, livestock owner, and hunter.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought I was going to the end of the world and they wouldn't see me again.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

On the road to Brandon in the fall of 1901

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Road from Brandon to Winnipeg via Prince Albert, Regina to Saskatoon.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

In the fall of 1901 I met James Brady, his afternoon driver. We stayed at Assiniboia and traveled with them. In June 1902 I hitched a car of freight to the Buffalo River station. The next day we arrived at the railway station. The next day we arrived at the Windsor Hotel. They didn't even have telephones there.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the Windsor Hotel. They didn't even have telephones there.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Saskatchewan, near Prince Albert, about 1/2 mile from the railroad.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived at Regina, Saskatchewan, from 1908 to 1911.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Farmers started on farms and bought their own farms. After moving to Canada, farming became more difficult.

On 1905, 1907, 1918. All settled at or near Mead, Saskatchewan.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

When we came out 1901, we had the most lovely summer weather, and Rachel (Ben) had the longest winter always. The way we used our fire. We never opened any window. We used the fire to keep warm and sleeping very comfortably when we lived in the cabin. We traveled about much in the early years. (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?
